Ranged projectile attacks freeze is midair so long as the power remains in effect, while melee weapons simply cease movement on contact with the barrier. It is impossible to move through the wall, and each creature attempting to do so must make a Dexterity saving throw. If the save is failed, the creature can’t move until the start of its next turn. Nonphysical attacks, such a telepathic attacks or magical energy can pass through the wall without incident.

You can empower this augmentation by spending additional power points. For every 2 power points spent, you create an additional 10-foot square panel. Additional panels must connect with another panel, but don’t have to be in a straight line.

11. Your inertial barrier becomes a stasis barrier. Each target it affects is frozen in time so long as the power remains in effect. Each creature affected must make a Dexterity saving throw. If successful the creature escapes the stasis field. In the case of a dome, the creature moves to the nearest unoccupied space outside the dome. If the save fails, the creature gains the stasis condition.
Detection: Psychic
You erect a mental fortress, warding psionic assaults. While this power is in effect, you have advantage on saving throws against mental spells and powers such charm person and ego whip.
1. Your thoughts can’t be read by any spell, power, or feature and you are aware when an attempt to do so is made against you.

You can empower this augmentation by spending an additional 2 power points (3) to allow you to mislead attempts to read your mind. Make an Intelligence (Deception) check against the target’s passive Wisdom (Insight) to reveal misleading or false information.
2. Increase the maintenance by 1 minute. You can take this augmentation multiple times.

4. Each creature within 10 feet you that you choose gains the same benefit as you do when you manifest this power. This protection will remain for another creature so long as this power remains in effect and the creature remains within 600 feet of you.
5. You can’t be located through scrying, clairvoyance, or similar means. Your presence is suppressed from such attempts.
7. You gain resistance to psychic damage and are immune to the traumatic effects of psychic impressions and the unsettled condition.

You can empower this augmentation by spending an additional 2 power points (9). When you succeed an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw to take reduced psychic damage, you instead take no damage.
Alternately, by spending 8 additional power points (15), you empower this augmentation to gain immunity to psychic damage.

13. When you are the target of a telepathic power, enchantment, telepathic spell, or similar feature, you can take a reaction to reflect the ability back to its source. The originator must then make an attack roll or saving throw against itself using its own spellcasting or power manifestation ability.
Only the manifester can benefit from this augmentation, additional targets from another augmentation can’t make reactions to reflect mental abilities.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (glow)

You create a 1/4 inch thick field of telekinetic force that can be used to protect yourself and others. Nothing can physically pass through the barrier, nor can it be moved through physical exertion. The barrier is immune to all damage. It can be disintegrated, but will automatically reform at the end of your next turn so long as this power remains in effect.

Increase the AC of a willing creature in range by 2. This bonus doesn’t stack with the bonus from a shield. The barrier remains with the creature unless an augmentation transforms it into a stationary barrier.
0. At 5th level the range increases by 30 feet (60 feet). At 11th level the range increases another 30 feet (90 feet), and against at 17th level (120 feet).
1. Increase the maintenance by 1 minute. You can take this augmentation multiple times.
3. Your barrier transforms into a wall of kinetic force. The wall is a 5-feet-by-5-feet panel that provides half cover for a creature behind it. A wall can target a creature or a space in range.

You can empower this augmentation by spending additional power points. By spending 4 additional power points (7), you grant three quarters cover for a creature behind it. By instead spending 12 additional power points (15), you can grant a creature full cover while behind the wall.

You can also empower this augmentation by spending 6 additional power points (9 or 13) to transform a wall that targets a creature back into a shield that grants the target cover. If the barrier is used to push a target, you may use your power attack modifier in place of Strength (Athletics). You can’t be pushed while you have a barrier.
4. You can give a shield to one additional creature in range or create an additional 2 wall panels. You can take this augmentation multiple times. Walls don’t have to be contiguous.
4. Using a bonus action you can reposition any of your kinetic barrier walls so long as they remain within range.
6. You can manifest this power as a reaction.
8. Increase the AC granted by a shield to +4.
11. You create a stationary dome of force with up to a 15-foot radius hemispherical dome that grants full cover and can’t be passed through.
You can empower this augmentation by spending 6 additional power points (17) which allows your dome to move when its target moves.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (overt)

You fashion your bones or other body parts into weapons, such as bone claws, long nails, or spike growths. You can make one or two living weapons when you manifest this power. You are proficient with these weapons, and you can use your manifesting ability modifier in place of Strength on attack and damage rolls. A living weapon can’t be disarmed. When you manifest this power, you choose whether your living weapon deals bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, and if you manifest two weapons at once, they don’t have to be the same damage type.

If you have a class feature that enables you to maintain more than one power through concentration, you can manifest this power again to stack additional effects on your living weapons. Stacked augmentations must be different augmentations. You can’t, for instance, manifest the attack bonus augmentation twice and stack those effects. Only the strongest augmentation takes effect.
Your living weapon deals 1d6 damage. If you are a creature larger in size than Medium, your living weapons gain a bonus to damage rolls (Large: +2, Huge: +4, Gargantuan: +8).

0. At 5th level you can maintain this power for 5 minutes. At 11th level you can maintain this power for 10 minutes. At 17th level, when forced to make a concentration save while this power is in effect, you treat any roll below 12 as a 12.
1. While this power is in effect and when you use the Attack action, you can use a bonus action to make an attack with your living weapon provided it was not used as part of your Attack action.
2. Your living weapon gains a +1 bonus on attack and damage rolls. You can take this augmentation multiple times up to 6 power points.
3. Your living weapon counts as a magical weapon for the purpose of overcoming damage resistance and immunity. It is still psychic and not magical for the purpose of dispel and suppression.
3. Upgrade your living weapon damage to 2d4.
You can empower this augmentation by spending an additional 4 power points (7) to increase its damage to 2d6.

5. Your living weapon causes blood loss to creatures capable of bleeding. A creature that takes damage from the living weapon must make a Constitution saving throw. If the save is failed, the creature takes 1d4 damage from blood loss at the start of each of its turns for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the creature makes a new save, which, if successful, ends the blood loss. A creature can only suffer blood loss from your living weapons once per turn. If the creature receives any healing, the creature stops bleeding from this power. A creature can also attempt a Wisdom (Medicine) check against your power save DC to end the bleeding by using its action.
5. You regain hit points equal to half the bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage your living weapon inflicts to a creature.
5. Your living weapon deals an extra 1d8 necrotic damage.

You can empower this augmentation by spending an additional 2 power points (7) to make creatures struck by your living weapon ill. When you hit a creature, it must make a Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for 1 minute.
5. Your living weapon deals an extra 1d8 acid damage.
You can empower this augmentation by spending additional power points. For every additional 4 power points you spend, increase the acid damage by 1d8 up to 8 power points.

9. When you hit a creature with your living weapon, you may take a bonus action to inflict an additional 3d6 weapon damage. If this damage reduces your target’s hit points to 0, you may make another attack against a different creature within reach.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (glow)

You grant a creature an astute understanding of the flow of combat, enhancing its combat abilities. While this power remains in effect, you have proficiency with all simple, martial, and improvised weapons, light, medium, and heavy armors, and shields. Your unarmed attacks deal 1d4 damage if not already better.
1. You deal an additional 1d4 weapon damage with melee and ranged weapon attacks.
You can empower this augmentation by spending an additional 4 power points (5) to increase this bonus damage to 1d6. By spending a further 4 power points (9), you increase this bonus to 2d4.
2. Increase the maintenance time by 1 minute. You can take this augmentation multiple times.

3. Once per round, you can use your reaction to make a riposte with a melee weapon you hold against a creature that attacks you with a melee weapon attack that is within your weapon’s reach. This attack will score a critical hit on a 19-20.
4. You can manifest this power using your reaction when you are attacked by a weapon attack. It will remain in effect until the start of your next turn unless you maintain it.
7. Each weapon attack you make scores a critical hit on a 19-20.

9. Once per round, you can use your reaction to cause any attack against you to automatically miss. If the attack is a melee attack, the creature making the attack is at disadvantage on each attack roll made against you until the end of its turn. If the attack is a ranged attack, you can use your reaction again this round.
11. You have expertise with any two weapons you choose. This allows you to double your proficiency bonus on attack rolls made with the selected weapons.

13. You gain 3 martial dice. You can expend a martial die to increase an attack roll or damage roll you make by 1d10. You can also use your reaction to spend a martial die to increase your AC by 1d10.
You can empower this augmentation to gain an extra martial die per 2 additional power points you spend up to 6 power points.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (glow)

You create a psionic barrier that intercepts telepathic and mental assaults. You gain a +1 bonus to your AC and saving throws against telepathic spells and powers and attacks that deal psychic damage until the start of your next turn.
1. Increase the bonus to AC and saving throws to +5 against telepathic powers and spells or attacks the deal psychic damage until the start of your next turn.
2. This power gains a range of 60 feet and can protect an allied creature.
3. Reduce psychic damage from each attack against you by 1d6 until the start of your next turn.
You can empower this augmentation, increasing the damage reduced by 1d6 per additional power point.

5. You can use your reaction to attempt to disrupt a telepathic power manifested within 60 feet of you of which you are aware. You make an ability check using your power manifestation ability against a DC equal to 10 + half the power points used to augment the power you are attempting to disrupt or against the manifester’s power save DC if it is from a creature ability or class feature that doesn’t use power points. On a success, the creature’s power fails and has no effect.

You can empower this augmentation to disrupt telepathic spells by spending an additional 6 power points (11). Make the same ability check, but against a DC equal to 10 + the spell’s level. On a success the spell fails and has no effect.
You can also empower this augmentation to gain a bonus on your ability check. For every 4 additional power points spend, you gain a +1 bonus.

This power can be further empowered to reflect telepathic and mind affecting powers back to its manifester by spending an extra 8 power points (13 or 19). The original manifester must make an attack roll using its own power attack modifier or a saving throw against its own power save DC as if it is the target. You are regarded as the manifester (or caster if empowered to affect spells) to determine the results of effects like charm or suggestion. If the manifester isn’t a valid target of the reflected power or spell, it has no effect.
7. You can’t be targeted by hostile telepathic or mind affecting powers or spells until the start of your next turn.
You can empower this augmentation by spending an additional 2 power points (9) to extend this protection for 1 minute, or an additional 8 power points (15) to extend it to 1 hour.

setters.set: 1 reaction, when you are the target of a telepathic attack or an attack that deals psychic damage

description.p: Detection: Psychic, Visual (glow, overt)

Through raw mental will, you manifest a shaped psychic weapon approximately the size of a short sword. Attacks made with a mind blade, or weapon imbued with a mind blade, are weapon attacks. You are considered proficient with this weapon, and it has the light and finesse traits. A mind blade deals 1d6 + your Strength modifier psychic damage on a successful hit. The mind blade is considered a magical weapon for overcoming damage resistance, not including weapons imbued with this power. A mind blade can’t be disarmed.
While this power is in effect, you can create a second mind blade using a bonus action allowing you to dual wield mind blades in each hand at once.

0. Your mind blade becomes stronger as you increase in level. At 5th level, the psychic damage of the mind blade increases by 2 points (1d6 + 2), at 11th level this bonus increases another 2 points (1d6 + 4), and once more at 17th level (1d6 + 6). This bonus affects weapons you imbue with your mind blade power as well.
1. You imbue one melee weapon with psychic energy, granting +2 psychic damage on each attack made with it while this power remains in effect.
You can empower this augmentation by spending an additional 2 power points (3) to imbue a ranged weapon or to imbue two melee weapons at once.
2. Each mind blade gains a +1 bonus on attack and damage rolls. Imbued weapons don’t benefit from this augmentation. You can take this augmentation multiple times up to 6 power points.

3. Each weapon imbued with your mind blade is treated as a magical weapon with a +1 bonus on attack and damage rolls. You must imbue a weapon to benefit from this augmentation. If a weapon already has a bonus from magic that is equal or greater than this bonus, this augmentation has no effect.
You can empower this augmentation by spending power points to upgrade the bonus. For every 2 additional power points you spend to do so, you increase the bonus by 1 up to 4 power points.
Detection: Psychic

While this power is in effect, you are able to read the surface thoughts of one creature in range by taking a bonus action. The creature must make an Intelligence saving throw. If the save is failed you know what it is thinking, whether it is lying or telling the truth, or if it is concealing information. You may only discern one parcel of information during your turn.

If the creature is distracted and unaware of your attention, it makes the save with disadvantage. The target creature must think in a language you understand or express strong feelings such as rage or hunger. A creature trained to protect its thoughts from telepathic reading may have means to mislead or stymie your efforts at the discretion of the DM.

While there are no direct benefits in combat, circumstance can provide tactical advantage. For instance, a creature may be thinking about luring the party into a trap, and reading its thoughts can make the manifester aware of this, allowing the manifester to alert the rest of the party or circumvent the creature’s plan another way.
0. Starting at 11th level, when you attempt to read or probe the mind of an incapacitated creature, it automatically fails its Intelligence save.
1. By taking a bonus action, you seek the answer to general knowledge questions, such as whether a specific person is at a certain location or if the creature is attempting to deceive you.

3. While reading thoughts, you attempt to make a subject think of a specific topic. You could learn when the watch shifts change at a warehouse, or you can cause the creature to think of the answer to the riddle it poses.
5. After successfully reading a creature’s mind you are freely able to read its every thought until the start of your next turn.

7. By taking a bonus action you probe the creature’s mind for information that you are aware exists. For example, if you know a creature knows the proper way to unlock a special locking mechanism, you can withdraw that procedure.

8. Whenever a creature resists your probe attempts (but not your mind reading attempts), you can use your reaction to mentally lash it. It must make another Intelligence saving throw. If the save is failed, it takes 4d6 psychic damage. If successful, the creature takes half the damage. On subsequent turns, the creature can voluntarily fail its save to resist your probe, avoiding the psychic damage.
You can empower this augmentation by spending additional power points. For every 2 additional power point2 you spend, increase the psychic damage by 1d6 up to 8 power points.

11. By taking a bonus action you delve for any information the subject possesses, including information you are unaware the subject possesses. When you probe its mind, you gain additional information about the topic. Secrets, scandalous information, and peculiar knowledge are most likely to be learned, your DM will decide what additional kernels you glean. On later turns, you can probe for further information regarding topics you uncover. For instance, you could root in the subject’s mind to find information about its king and discover the king is an imposter, and on later turns find out who is involved with the conspiracy.
Detection: Psychic, Gesture, Visual (beam)
A spear of psychic energy arcs toward a creature in range. You must make a ranged power attack roll. Missiles deal 1d8 psychic damage.
0. At 5th level, you deal an additional 1d8 damage (2d8). At 11th level, your damage increases by another 1d8 (3d8), and once again at 17th level, (4d8).
1. Your missiles ignore cover and may target creatures behind barriers without line of sight if you know they are there.
2. Increase the damage by 1d8. You can take this augmentation multiple times.
3. You create an additional psychic spear which must target a different creature. You can take this augmentation multiple times.

5. Your psychic spears explode on impact in a 5-foot radius. Each creature within the area, except the spear’s target, must make an Intelligence saving throw. If the save is failed, the creature takes half the damage of the spear. If the save is successful, the creature takes no damage.
You can empower this augmentation. For every 3 additional power points, increase the radius by 5 feet.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (beam, glow)
You pierce a creature’s mind, inflicting 1d12 psychic damage. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. If successful, the target takes no damage.
0. This power’s damage increases by 1d12 at 5th level (2d12), again at 11th level (3d12), and once again at 17th level (4d12).
1. A target damaged by this power is at disadvantage on Intelligence (Investigation) and Wisdom (Perception) checks for 1 minute.
You can empower this augmentation by spending 4 additional power points (5). A target also has disadvantage on ranged attacks rolls for 1 minute.
2. Increase the damage by 1d12. You can take this augmentation multiple times.
3. A creature that takes damage from this power can’t gain advantage on attack rolls until the end of its next turn.

You can empower this augmentation to endure for 1 minute by spending an additional 6 power points (9). At the end of each of its turns, the creature makes a new Wisdom saving throw, which, if successful, frees it from this affliction.
7. A creature that takes damage from this power is blinded and deafened until the end of its next turn. It also can’t benefit from blindsight and tremorsense for the same period.
You can empower this augmentation by spending 6 additional power points (13) to extend the duration of these conditions to 1 minute.
11. A target that suffers damage from this power has the synaptic static condition until the end of its next turn.

You can empower this augmentation. For every additional power point you spend, synaptic static lasts for 1 round. The target makes a Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If successful, the condition is removed.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (glow)
You link minds with a willing creature within 30 feet of you. This link persists over any distance so long as you remain on the same plane of existence. Unwilling creatures can’t be linked.
While linked, you and each linked creatures can send a telepathic message to each member of the link you choose by taking a bonus action. Members must share a common language to understand messages.

Each linked creature also gains the Hive Mind trait. Hive Mind grants each member of the link a +1 bonus on its first attack roll against a target another member has damaged until the start of that member’s next turn.

0. At 5th level you may add two additional creatures to the link (3 creatures). At 11th level you may add two more creatures (5 creatures), and two additional creatures again at 17th level (7 creatures).
1. Each member of the Hive Mind within 240 feet of another member gains a +1d4 bonus on initiative rolls.

This augmentation can be empowered by spending 4 additional power points (5). Whenever one member of the link within 240 is not surprised by an encounter, no member of the link is surprised. Additionally, each member’s Passive Perception is increased to the highest member’s Passive Perception within 240 feet.
2. You enhance Hive Mind, granting a +1 bonus on damage rolls to members who benefit from the attack roll bonus of Hive Mind.
You can empower this augmentation. For every 4 additional power points you spend, increase the bonus to attack and damage rolls by 1.
You can also empower this augmentation by spending 8 power points (10). Whenever a member has an attack bonus from Hive Mind, it makes its attack roll with advantage.

3. Each linked creature can transmit rough concepts to beasts and other creatures with limited language capacity within the link. The creature must have an Intelligence of 4 or less. Beasts can transmit simple sentiments, such as “danger” or “distrust.” The beast may not necessarily take the action you want.
You can empower this augmentation. By spending an additional 6 power points (9) you can transmit thoughts to a creature without sharing a common language regardless of the creature’s intelligence.

4. While this power is in effect, you can use your action to add an additional willing creature to the link or remove an existing member (other than you). You can only have a number of creatures equal to your level linked at a time.
6. Transmitting thoughts no longer requires a bonus action and can be done at will during a linked creature’s turn.

7. You can share sensory data with members of the link. You can either transmit to each member of the link you choose or you can retrieve sensory data from one member of the group you choose. This allows you to see, hear, etc. as another member of the link senses or to share your sensations to each linked member you choose.

If a member of the group possesses blindsight, darkvision, tremorsense or another sensory trait, each member of the link shares that trait so long as the member providing the trait isn’t incapacitated.
13. Each beneficial telepathic power or mind-affecting spell, such as heroism or Bardic Inspiration, that targets a linked member targets all members of the link.

You can empower this augmentation by spending 4 additional power points (17). Each member of the link can use the Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw of the member with the highest value. Whenever a member of the link would lose concentration on a spell or power, another member can use its reaction to assume concentration to persist the effect. At the end of the next linked creature’s turn the caster or manifester must resume concentration or the effect ends. This power is a valid target for this feature. If the member is a spell caster of the same class as an assumed spell’s concentration or a manifester of a class in which the power is on its list of potential power, the creature can fully assume concentration on that spell or power. The spell or power remains at its original casting or manifesting strength. A spell will end when its duration runs out. A power will cause psychic strain when its maintenance time is exceeded.
Detection: Psychic
Feeding false sensory information to a creature’s mind, you alter its perception.

You create the sensation of a minor effect, such as a knocking sound, flashing lights, or strong odor in the creature’s mind. The creature must make an Intelligence saving throw. If the save is failed, the creature is at disadvantage on Perception checks and has its Passive Perception reduced by 5.

1. You alter a creature’s physical senses, such as vision or hearing. You can decide what the subject senses (or doesn’t sense) if it fails an Intelligence saving throw. For instance, you could make it so a guard doesn’t see or hear your group walk by it. At the start of each of its turns, the creature makes a new Intelligence saving throw.
If the creature takes damage, this power ends.

By spending 6 additional power points (7) you can empower this augmentation to not break when the creature takes damage. In this case it makes a new Intelligence saving throw whenever it takes damage.
2. You target one additional creature within range. You can take this augmentation multiple times.

5. If it fails its saving throw, the creature’s senses are disrupted, causing it to see blurs and shadows, hear disembodied voices, etc. The creature is at disadvantage on attack rolls and Wisdom checks. At the end of each of its turns or whenever it takes damage, the creature makes a new Intelligence saving throw to break the effects.

11. Sending a creature deep into its own thoughts, you effectively trap it in a prison of its own mind. The creature must make an Intelligence saving throw. If the save is failed, the creature has no idea of what is happening around it, instead feeling trapped in the ether. The creature may use its action to attempt to escape. When it does so, it makes a DC 20 Intelligence check. If it succeeds, it escapes and the power ends.

Since the target creature is still exactly where it started, it can be acted upon while it is in this state. Functionally, the creature is paralyzed. If the creature receives damage, this power immediately ends.

By spending 6 additional power points (17) you can empower this augmentation to not break when the creature takes damage, creating a dreamlike sensation of its surroundings as they affect it. When the creature takes damage it makes its Intelligence check with advantage.
Detection: Psychic, Gesture, Visual (beam)

You excite molecules of an inorganic, unattended object or a 5-foot cube section of a Large object or surface. Each attack made against the object deals an additional 1d6 weapon damage if the attack is from a weapon or an extra 1d6 spell or power damage if the attack is from a spell or power.
0. At 5th level, destabilized molecules take an additional 1d6 damage (2d6). At 11th level this increases by another 1d6 (3d6), and once again at 17th level (4d6).

1. You can make an attended object such as a weapon or armor unstable. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. If the save is failed, the object is destabilized. Each weapon affected has a -2 penalty on attack and damage rolls. Armor has is AC reduced by 2, but its base AC can’t be reduced below 10.

3. Instead of destabilizing molecules, you cause one inorganic object in range, such as a suit of armor or a 5-foot section of stone floor to become red-hot or ice-cold. Each creature in physical contact with the object takes 2d8 fire (if hot) or cold (if cold) damage when you manifest the power. So long as this power remains in effect, the creature takes 1d4 damage of the same type at the start of each of its turns.

If a creature is holding or wearing the object and takes damage from it, the creature must succeed a Constitution saving throw or drop the object if it can. If it doesn’t drop the object, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of its next turn.
You can empower this augmentation. For every 4 power points spent this way increase the initial damage by 1d8 and the damage dealt per round by 1d4.

3. You can cause wood, leather, and cloth objects to combust, taking 2d8 fire damage at the end of each of your turns. Each creature in physical contact with the object takes 1d8 fire damage when you manifest this power and another 1d8 fire damage at the start of each of its turns so long as this power is in effect. If the creature is holding the item, it must succeed a Constitution saving throw or drop the item if able. The creature may use its action to remove worn items, but suffers 2d8 fire damage for doing so.
Once an object is destroyed it no longer burns.
4. You can target an additional object within range or an additional 5-foot cube section of a surface or Large object. You can take this augmentation multiple times.

7. You transform an unattended object or section of matter into a semi-corporeal state. A semi-corporeal object can be passed through as if it is difficult terrain. If a creature or object is within the affected area when the power expires, it is moved to the nearest unoccupied space without harm.

You can empower this augmentation by spending 4 additional power points (11) to target an object held or worn by a creature. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. If the save succeeds, the object is unaffected. An affected object is dropped to the ground and can’t be retrieved until this power expires. A magical item can’t be affected by this power.

13. A creature’s or object’s molecules are disrupted. If a creature is the target, it must make a Constitution saving throw. If the save is failed, the creature takes 5d8 + 15 force damage. If the target is reduced to 0 hit points it and all nonmagical equipment it carries are reduced to goo. A creature can be restored to life only by means of a true resurrection or a wish spell.

Medium or smaller nonmagical objects are immediately destroyed. If the target is a Large or larger object, a 5-foot cube ortion of it is rendered to dust. A magical item is not affected by this power.

Maintaining this power allows you use your action on subsequent turns to continue disintegrating the same creature or object. A Large or larger object has an additional 5-foot cube portion rendered to dust. A creature takes 3d8 + 9 force damage on subsequent turns when you use your action. If you don’t use your action to continue disintegrating your target, this power ends.

If you augment this power to target multiple objects, you can target additional creatures instead. Each creature or object must be within 5 feet of another creature or object affected by this power. If a target moves beyond 5 feet of another, you must decide on which target to maintain this power.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (glow)
Entering a hyperaware state, you can glimpse actions and events against you moments before they happen, giving you a greater opportunity to avoid or avert such events and their results.

While this power is in effect, you can use your reaction to reroll any attack roll, saving throw, or ability check made by you or against you. If the roll has advantage or disadvantage, the reroll is also made with advantage or disadvantage. You must accept the result of the new roll.
1. When you use your reaction to reroll an attack made against it you, it no longer has advantage. If the attack didn’t have advantage, then this augmentation has no effect on it.

When you use your reaction to reroll an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw you make, it no longer has disadvantage. If you didn’t have disadvantage on the roll, this augmentation has no effect on it.
3. Gaining a perfect sense of how your movement will play out, you gain advantage on any Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) checks and Dexterity saving throws.
5. The first attack made against you each round has disadvantage. You also increase your AC by 4 against opportunity attacks.
7. While this power is in effect, whenever you succeed a Dexterity saving throw to reduce the damage you take, you, instead, take no damage.
8. Once per round when you use your reaction with this power, your reaction is immediately refreshed and available for use again.
You can empower this augmentation to instead trigger twice per round by spending an additional 6 power points (14).
9. When you use your reaction to make a new saving throw or force an attacker to reroll, you reduce the damage from that attack by 2d10.
You can empower this augmentation. For every 3 additional power points spent this way increase the damage reduction by 1d10.
11. Once per round, you can automatically avoid one attack that required an attack roll or pass one saving throw. This doesn’t require your reaction.
Detection: Psychic, Visual (glow)

You control the chaotic force of chance, pivoting the odds to your favor or the disfavor of another. This power displays as random events of good or bad luck, such as straps loosening or a stone rolling under foot.

You grant either a boon or a hex upon a creature within range. Once per round, a creature under a boon adds 1d4 to an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw that you choose. Once per round, a hexed creature subtracts 1d4 from an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw of your choice. You can choose which roll to modify after knowing the result of the die.
A creature targeted by a hex must make a Charisma saving throw. If successful, the creature is not affected by your power.
A remove curse spell will remove this power from a creature.

Detection: Psychic, Gesture, Visual (beam, glow)

Detection: Psychic

You create vibrations and shockwaves of psychokinetic force. Choose a 5-foot square on a surface within 30 feet of you. Each creature standing on that surface must make a Dexterity saving throw. If the save is failed the creature is knocked prone.

You can control the wind and the rains, bending the weather to your will.

1. You create an eye in your storm anywhere within your effect area. This eye is a 5-foot diameter.

You may take a bonus action to reposition one line of wind while this power remains in effect.

5. You create a sleet storm that affects a 20-foot tall cylinder with a 40-foot radius centered on a point within your effect area that you choose. If the wind is strong, the entire area acts as a gust in one direction. Each creature that starts its turn within the effect area must succeed a Strength saving throw or be pushed 15 feet in the direction of the wind. Any creature within the area must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves while moving against the wind. If the save is successful, the creature takes half damage.
